editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The iron age: containing the rape of Helen: the siege of Troy: the combat betwixt Hector and Aiax: Hector and Troilus slain by Achilles: Achilles slain by Paris: Aiax and Ulysses contend for the armour of Achilles: the death of Aiax, etc. written by Thomas Heywood.
Printed at London by Nicholas Okes. 1632.

list.head: Of the party of the Trojans.
Of the party of the Grecians.
list.item: Castor and Pollux, the two brothers of Helena.

div.p: The iron age: containing the rape of Helen: the siege of Troy: the combat betwixt Hector and Aiax: Hector and Troilus slain by Achilles: Achilles slain by Paris: Aiax and Ulysses contend for the armour of Achilles: the death of Aiax, etc. written by Thomas Heywood.

figure.p: Tam Robur · tam robor. Ni-colis arbor jovis. 1610.

div.p: Printed at London by Nicholas Okes. 1632.

list.head: Of the party of the Trojans.
Of the party of the Grecians.
list.item: Castor and Pollux, the two brothers of Helena.

div.head: To my worthy and much respected friend, Mr. Thomas Hammon, of Gray's inn esquire.
div.p: If the noble scholar nichod. Friseelimus, thought that his labour in transferring six of Aristophanes' his comedies, out of the original Greek into the Roman tongue, was worthy to be dedicated to six several, the most eminent princes of his time, for learning and judgement: think it then no disparagement to you, to undertake as well the patronage, perusal of this poem: which as it exceeds the strict limits of the ancient comedy (Then in use) inform, so it transcends them many degrees; both in the fullness of the scene, and gravity of the subject.

The history whereon it is grounded, having been the selected argument of many exquisite poets ▪ for what pen of note, in one page or other
hath not remembered Troy, and bewailed the sack, and subversion of so illustrious a city ▪ which, although it were situate in Asia, yet out of her ashes hath risen, two the rarest phoenixes in Europe, namely London and Rome ▪ sir my acquaintance with your worth, and knowledge of your judgement, were the chief motives, inducing me to select you before many others: accept it, I entreat you, as favourably as he exposeth it willingly, who as he hath antecedently long, so futurely ever,

div.head: To the reader.
div.p: Courteous reader: the gold, silver, and brass ages having been many years since in the press, continuing the history from Jupiter's birth (The son of Saturn) to the death of Hercules. This iron age (Never till now published,) beginneth where the other left, holding on, a plain and direct course, from the second rape of Helen: (For she was in her minority ravished by Theseus the friend of Hercules) not only to the utter ruin, and devastation of Troy; but it, with the second part, stretcheth to the deaths of Helen, and all those Kings of Greece, who were the undertakers of that ten years bloody and fatal siege. I presume the reading there of shall not prove distasteful unto any ▪ first in regard of the antiquity and nobleness of the history: next because it includeth the most things of especial remark, which have been ingeniously commented, and laboriously recorded, by the muse's darlings, the poets: and times learned remembraneers; the historiographers ▪

Lastly, I desire thee to take notice, that these were the plays often (And not with the least applause,) publicly acted by two companies, upon one stage at once, and have at sundry times thronged three several theatres, with numerous and mighty auditories, if the grace they had then in the actings, take not away the expected luster, hoped for in the reading, I shall then hold thee well pleased, and therein, myself fully satisfied; ever remaining thine as studious ▪

div.head: Actus primus, scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter King Priamus, Queen Hecuba, Hector, Troilus, Aeneas, Deiphobus, etc.

sp.speaker: Priamus.
sp.l: Princes and sons of Priam, to this end
We called you to this solemn parlance ▪
There's a divining spirit prompts me still ▪
That if we new begin hostility,
The Grecians may be forced to make repair
Of our twice ruined walls, and of the rape
Done to our sister fair Hesione.
Aeneas. I am my princely sovereign of your mind,
And can by grounded arguments approve
Your power and potency: what they twice demolished,
Is now with strength and beauty reared again.
Your kingdom grown more populous and rich ▪
The youth of Troy irregular and untamed,
Covetous of war and martial exercise.
From you and silver tressed Hecuba
Fifty fair sons are lineally derived,
All Asia's Kings are in your love and league ▪
Their royalties as of your empire held ▪
Hector and Hector's brothers are of power
To fetch your sister from the heart of Greece,
Where she remains embraced by Telamon.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Aeneas, your advice assents with us.
How stand our sons unto these wars inclined?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: In mine opinion we have no just cause
To raise new tumults, that may live in peace:
War is a fury quickly conjured up,
But not so soon appeased ▪

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What juster cause ▪
When the whole world takes note to our disgrace,
Of this our Troy, twice raced by Hercules.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: And fair Hesione rapt hence to Greece,
Where she still lives cooped up in Salamine.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Troy, was twice raced, and Troy deserved that wrack,
The valiant (Half divine bred) Hercules,
Redeemed this town from black mortality,
And my bright aunt from death, when he surcharged
The virgin fed, sea-monster with his club.
For my own grand-sire great Laomedon,
Denied the hero, both the meed proposed,
And most (Ingrateful) shut him from the gates:
Troy therefore drew just ruin on itself:
'Tis true, our aunt was born away to Greece,
Who with more justice might transport her hence,
Than he whose prize she was? bold Telamon
For venturing first upon the walls of Troy,
Alcides gave her to the Salmine Duke.
Detaining her? whom keeps he but his own?
Were she my prisoner I should do the like.
By Jove she's worth the keeping.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then of force,
She must be worth the fetching.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Fetch her that list: my reverent King and father ▪
If you pursue this expedition,
By the untaunted honour of these arms
That live emblazoned on my burnished shield ▪
it is without good cause, and I divine
Of all your flourishing line, by which the gods
Have rectified your fame above all Kings,
Not one shall live to meat your sepulchre,
Or trace your funeral heralds to the tombs
Of your great ancestors: o for your honour
Take not up unjust arms.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Prince Hector's words
Will draw on him the imputation
Of fear and cowardice.

sp.speaker: ▪ Troi.
sp.l: Fie brother Hector,
If our aunt's rape, and Troy's destruction
Be not revenged, their several blemishes
The aged hand of time can never wipe
From our succession.
'Twill be registered
That all King Priam's sons save one were willing
And forward to revenge them on the Greeks,
Only that Hector durst not.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Ha, durst not didst thou say? effeminate boy ▪
Go get you to your sheephook and your scrip,
Thou lookest not like a soldier, there's no fire
Within thine eyes, nor quills upon thy chin,
Tell me I dare not? go, rise, get you gone:
Thou'rt fitter for young Oenon's company
Then for a bench of soldiers: here comes one,
Antenor is returned.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Welcome Antenor, what's the news from Greece?

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: News of dishonour to the name of Priam,
Your highness' sister fair Hesione▪
Esteemed there as a strumpet, and no Queen;
(After complaint) when I proposed your majesty
Would fetch her thence perforce, had you but seen
With what disdainful pride, and bitter taunts
They tossed my threats: 'twould have inflamed your spleen
With more than common rage, never was Princess
so basely used: never ambassador
With such dishonour sent from princes' court,
As was then from that of Telamon's,
Of Agamemnon's and the Spartan Kings.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: I shall not die in peace, if these disgraces
Live unrevenged.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: By Jove we'll fetch her thence,
Or make all populous Greece a wilderness,
Paris a hand, we are friends, now Greece shall find
And thou shalt know what mighty Hector dares.
When all th'united Kings in arms shall rue
This base dishonour done to Priam's blood.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hear gracious sir, my dream in Ida mount,
Beneath the shadow of a cedar sleeping.
Celestial Juno, Venus, and the goddess
Born from the brain of mighty Jupiter.
These three present me with a golden ball,
On which was writ, detur pulcherrimae,
Give't to the fairest: Juno proffers wealth,
Sceptres and crowns: saith, she will make me rich ▪
Next steps forth Pallas with a golden book,
Saith, reach it me, I'll teach the literature,
Knowledge and arts, make thee of all most wise.
Next smiling Venus' came, with such a look
Able to ravish mankind: thus bespoke me,
Make that ball mine? the fairest Queen that breathes,
I'll in requital, cast into thine arms.
How can I stand against her golden smiles,
When beauty promised beauty? she prevailed:
To her I gave the prize, with which she mounted
Like to a star from earth shot up to heaven.
Now if in Greece (As some report) be ladies
Peerless for beauty, wherefore might not Paris
By Venus' aid sail hence to Grecia,
And quit the rape of fair Hesione,
By stealing thence the Queen most beautiful ▪
That feeds upon the honey of that air?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: That amorous goddess born upon the waves
Assist thee in thy voyage, we will rig
A royal fleet to waft thee into Greece.
Aeneas with our son Deiphobus,
And other lords shall bear thee company.
What think our sons Hector and Troilus
Of Paris expedition?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: As an attempt the heavens have cause to prosper.
Go brother Paris, if thou bringest a Queen,
Hector will be her champion; then let's see
What Greek dare fetch her hence.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Straight give order
To have his fleet made ready.

div.stage: Enter Cassandra with her hair about her ears.

sp.speaker: Cassan.
sp.l: Stay Priam, Paris cease, stay Trojan peers
To plot your universal overthrow.
What hath poor Troy deserved, that you should kindle
Flames to destroy it?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What intends Cassandra ▪

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: To quench bright burning Troy, to secure thee,
To save old Priam and his fifty sons.
(The royal'st issue, that e'er King I enjoyed)
To keep the reverent hairs of Hecuba,
From being torn off by her own sad hands ▪

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Cassandra's mad.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: You are mad, all Troy is mad.
And rails before it's ruin.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What would my sister?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Stay this bold youth my brother, who by water
Would sail to bring fire which shall burn all Troy.
Stay him, o stay him ▪ ere these golden roofs
Melt o'er our heads before these glorious turrets
Be burned to ashes. Ere clear streams Simois
Run with blood royal, and Scamander plain,
In which Troy stands be made a sepulchre
To bury Troy, and Trojans.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Away with her, some false divining spirit
Envying the honour we shall gain from Greece,
Would trouble our designments.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Royal sir,
Cassandra is a vestal prophetess,
And consecrate to Pallas; oft inspired,
Then lend her gracious audience.

sp.speaker: Troil.
sp.l: So let our aunt
Be still a slave in Greece, and we your sons
Be held as cowards.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Let Antenor's wrongs
Be basely swallowed, and the name of Troy
Be held a word of scorn.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Then let Troy burn,
Let the Greeks clap their hands, and warm themselves
At this bright bonfire: dreamed not Hecuba
The night before this fatal youth was born,
That she brought forth a firebrand?

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: 'Tis most true.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: And when King Priam to the priest revealed
This ominous dream, he with the gods consulted,
And from the oracle did this return,
That the child born should stately Ilion burn.

sp.speaker: Par
sp.l: And well the prophet guest, for my desire
To visit Greece, burns with a quenchless fire:
Not from this flaming brand shall I be free,
Till I have left rich Troy, and Sparta see.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Yet Hecuba, ere thou thy Priam lose,
And Priam ere thou lose thy Hecuba,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Away with her.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Why speaks not in this case Andromache?
Thou shalt lose a Hector, who's yet thine.
Why good Aeneas dost thou speech forbear?
Thou hopest in time another Troy to rear,
When this is sacked, and therefore thou standst mute,
All struck with silence; none assist my suit.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Force her away and lay her fast in hold.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Then Troy, no Troy, but ashes; and a place
Where once a city stood: poor Priam, thou
That shalt leave fatherless fifty fair sons,
And this thy fruitful Queen, a desolate widow ▪
And Ilium now no palace for a King,
But a confused heap of twice burned brick.
They that thy beauty wondered, shall admire
To see thy towers defaced with Greekish fire.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thou art no sibyl, but from fury speak'st,
Not inspiration we regard thee not.
Come valiant sons, we'll first prepare our ships,
And with a royal fleet well rigged to sea
Seek just revenge for fair Hesione.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes, manet Paris, to him Oenon who in his go out plucks her back.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Know you not me?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Who art thou?

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: View me well.
And what I am, my looks and tears will teach thee ▪

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oenon? what brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: To see Ida bare
Of her tall cedars, to see shipwrights square
The trunks of new felled pines: asking the cause,
So many hatchets, hammers, ploughs and saws
Were thither brought: they 'gan me thus to greet ▪
With these tall cedars we must build a fleet
For Paris; who in that must sail to Greece,
To fetch a new wife thence.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And my fair Oenon,
Know that they told truth, for 'tis decreed
Even by the god's behest, that I should speed
Upon this new adventure: the gods all,
That made me judge to give the golden ball.
Hark, hark, the sailors cry aboard, aboard;
The wind blows fair, farewell.

sp.speaker: Oenon.
sp.l: Hear me one word.
By our first love, by all our amorous kisses ▪
Courtings, embraces, and ten thousand blesses
I conjure thee, that thou in Troy mayest stay.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: They cry aboard, and Paris must away.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: What needest thou plow the seas to seek a wife ▪
Having one here, to hazard thy sweet life,
Seeking a strumpet through wars fierce alarms,
And have so kind a wife lodged in thine arms.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sweet Oenon, stay me not, unclasp thine hold.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Not for Troy's crown or all the sun-god's gold ▪
Canst thou? o canst thou thy sweet life endanger,
And leave thine own wife to seek out a stranger?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I can ▪ farewell.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: O yet a little stay.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Let go thine hold, or I shall force my way ▪

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: O do but look on me, yet once again.
Though now a prince, thou wast an humble swain,
And then I was thine Oenon. (O sad fate)
I crave thy love, I covet not thy state;
Still I am Oenon: still thou Paris are
The selfsame man, but not the selfsame heart ▪

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Untie, or I shall break thy charming band,
Neptune assist my course: thou Jove my hand.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Most cruel, most unkind, hadst thou thus said
The night before thou hadst my maidenhead ▪
I had been free to choose, and thou to wive;
Not widowed now, my husband still alive.

div.stage: Enter King Menelaus, King Diomed, Thersites, a lord ambassador with attendants.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: King Diomed, Sparta is proud to see you,
Your coming at this time's more seasonable,
In that we have employment for your wisdom
And royal valour.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: The Christian sceptre now in controversy
(As this ambassador hath late informed)
Despising that usurping hand, which long
Hath against law and justice swayed and born it ▪
Offers itself to your protection.
Is it not so my lord?

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: You truly understand our embassy.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Menelaus!

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What saith Thersites?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: That heaven hath many stars in't, but no eyes ▪
And cannot see desert. The goddess fortune
Is hoodwinked, why else should she proffer thee
Another crown that hath one: (Grand sir Jove)
What a huge heap of business shalt thou have,
Having another kingdom? being in Crete,
Sparta will go to wrack, being in Sparta,
Crete will to ruin: to have more than these
Such a bright lass as Helen: Helen? o!
'Must have an eye to her too, fie, fie, fie,
Poor man how thou'lt be puzzled!

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Why thinks Thersites my bright Helen's beauty
Is not with her fair virtues equalised?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Yes, I think so, and Helen is an ass,
But thou believest so too.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Thersites is a railer.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: No, I disclaim't, I am a counsellor ▪
I have known a fellow matched to a fair wife,
That hath had never a kingdom: thou hast two
To look to, (Scarce a house) thou many palaces,
He scarce a page, and thou a thousand servants:
Yet he having no more, yet had too much
To look to one fair wife.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Were not the King
Well grounded in the virtues of his Queen,
Thy words Thersites might set odds betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: My Helen? therein am I happiest.
Know Diomed, her beauty I prefer
Before the crowns of Sparta, and of Crete.
Music! I know my lady then is coming ▪
To give kind welcome to King Diomed,
Strow in her way sweet powders, burn perfume,
And where my Helen treads no feet presume.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: 'Twere better strow horn-shavings.

div.stage: Enter Hellen with waiting gentlewomen and servants.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: 'Tis told is this ambassador doth stay
To take my husband, my dear lord away.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: True Helen, 'tis a kingdom calls me hence.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: A kingdom! hath your Helen such small grace,
That you prefer a kingdom 'fore her face?
You value me too cheap, and do not know ▪
The worth and value of the face you owe.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: I had rather have a good calf's face.

sp.speaker: Hes●.
sp.l: Theseus, that in my nonage did assail me,
And being too young for pastime, thence did hail me:
He, to have had the least part of your bliss
Oft proffered me a kingdom for a kiss.
You surfeit in your pleasures, swim in sport,
But sir, from henceforth I shall keepe you short.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Fair Queen, 'tis honour calls him hence away,

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: What's that to Helen, if she'll have him stay ▪
Say I should weep at parting, (Which I fear)
Some for ten kingdoms would not have a tear
Fall from his Helen's eye, but he's unkind,
And cares not though I weep my bright eyes blind.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Great King, we have discovered from the shore
A gallant fleet of ships, that with full sail
Make towards the port.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What number?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Some two and twenty sail.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Discover them more amply, and make good the haven against them, till we know th'intent of their arrive.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: My royal lord I shall.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Ambassador this business once blown o'er,
You shall receive your answer instantly.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: You shall not go and leave your Helen here,
Can I a kingdom govern in your absence,
And guide so rude a people as yours is?
How shall I do my lord, when you are gone,
So many bleak cold nights to lie alone?
You've used me so to fellowship in bed,
That should I leave it, I should soon be dead:
Troth I shall never endure it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: My sweet Helen,
Was never King blessed with so chaste a wife.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The news? whence is their fleet?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: From Troy.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The general?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Priam's son.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Their expedition?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: To seek adventures and strange lands abroad ▪
And though now weather-beat, yet braver men,
More rich in jewels, costlier arrayed,
Or better featured never eye beheld,
Especially the prince their general,
Paris of Troy one of King Priam's sons.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Braver then these our Lacedaemon's are ▪

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Madam, by much.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: How is the prince of Troy
To Menelaus mighty spartans' King?

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Prince Menelaus is my sovereign madam,
But might I freely speak without offence,
(Excepting Menelaus) never breathed
A braver gallant than the Trojan prince.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: What entertainment shall we give these strangers?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: What? but the choice that Lacedaemon yields,
If they come brave, our bravery let us show,
That what our Sparta yields, their Troy may know:
Let them not say they found us poor and bare.
Or that our Grecian ladies are less fair
Than theirs: give them occasion to relate
At their return, how we exceed their stare.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Helen hath well advised, and for the best
Her counsel with our honour doth agree,
All Sparta's pomp is for the Trojans free.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: O had I known their landing one day sooner,
That Helen might have trimmed up her attire
Against this meeting ▪ then my radiant beauty
I doubt not, might in Troy be termed as fair,
As through all Greece I am reputed rare.

div.stage: A flourish. Enter Paris, Aeneas, Deiphobus, Antenor, Menelaus and Diomed embrace Paris and the rest: Paris turns from them and kisseth Hellen, all way she with her hand puts him back.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: 'Tis not the Spartan fashion thus to greet
Upon the lips, when royal strangers meet.
I know not what your Asian courtship is.
O Jove, how sweetly doth this Trojan kiss?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Bear with a stranger lady ▪ though unknown;
That's practised in no fashion save his own.
He that his fault confesseth never offends ▪
Nor can he injure, that no wrong intends,

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: To kiss me! why before so many eyes
The King could do no more: would fortune bring
This stranger there where I have met the King ▪

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Patience, sweet Helen, Trojans welcome all,
You shall receive the princeliest entertain
Sparta can yield you, but some late affairs
About the Cretan sceptre calls us hence,
That business once determined we are yours,
In the mean time fair Helen be't your charge
To make their welcome in my absence large.

div.stage: They all go off with a flourish, only Paris and Hellen keep the stage.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O Jove my dream! sweet Venus aid my prayer ▪
And keep thy word: behold a face more fair
Than thou thyself canst show, this is the same
Thou promised me in Ida, this I claim.
Give me this face fair Venus, and that's all
I'll ask in guerdon of the golden ball.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Of what rare mettle is this Trojan made?
That one poor kiss hath power so to persuade,
Here at my lips the sweetness did begin,
And since hath passed through all my powers within:
O kiss me if thou lovest me once again,
I feel the first kiss thrill through every vein.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Queen I must speak with you,

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Must?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Helen, ay,
I have but two ways to take, to speak, or die:
Grant my tongue pardon then, or turn your head
And say you will not, and so strike me dead.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Live and say on, but if your words offend,
If my tongue can destroy, you're near your end.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O Jove, that I had now an angel's voice
As you an angel's shape have, that my words
Might sound as sphere-like music in your ear.
That Jove himself whom I must call to witness,
Would now stand forth in person to approve
What I now speak, Helen, Helen I love.
Chide me, I care not; tell ▪ your husband, do,
Fearless of death, behold, I boldly woe ▪
For let me live, bright Helen to enjoy,
Or let me never back resail to Troy:
For you I came, your fame hath hither driven me,
Whom golden Venus hath by promise given me.
I loved you ere I saw you by your fame,
Report of your rare beauty to Troy came ▪
But more than bruit can tell, or fame emblazon
Are these divine perfections that I gaze on.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Insolent stranger, is my name so light
abroad in Troy, that thou at the first sight
Shouldst hope to strum pet us? thinks Priam's son,
The Spartan Queen can be so easily won?
Because once Theseus ravished us from hence,
And did to us a kind of violence:
Follows it therefore we are of such price,
That stolen hence once, we should be ravished twice?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That Theseus stole you hence (By heaven) I praise him,
And for that act I to the skies will raise him.
That he returned you back by Jove I wonder,
Had I been Theseus, he that should asunder
Have parted us, and snatched you from my bed:
First from my should shoulders have ta'en this head.
O that you were the prize of some great strife,
And he that wins might claim you as his wife,
Yourself should find, and all the world should see
Helen, a prize alone ordained for me.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I am not angry; who can angry be
With him that loves her? they that Paris see,
And hears the wonders and rare deeds you boast,
And warlike spoils in which you glory most:
By which you have attained 'mongst soldiers' grace,
None can believe you that beholds your face.
They that this lovely Trojan see, will say;
He was not made for war, but amorous plays

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Love amorous Paris then.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My fame to endanger?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I can be secret lady.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: And a stranger?
Say I should grant thee love, as thou shouldst climb
My long wished bed; if at th'appointed time
The wind should alter, and blow fair for Troy,
Thou must break off in midst of all thy joy.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Not for great Sparta's crown, or Asia's treasure,
(That exceeds Sparta's) would I lose such pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Would it were come to that.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Your husband Menelaus hither bring,
compare our shapes, our youth and every thing,
I make you judgesse, wrong me if you can:
You needs must say I am the properer man.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I must confess that too.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then love me lady.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Had you then set sail,
When my virginity, and bed to enjoy
A thousand gallant princely suitors came?
Had I beheld thee first, I here proclaim,
Your feature should have born me from the rest.
You come too late, and covet goods possessed.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I came from Helen, Helen's love I crave,
Helen I love, and Helen I must have:
Or in this province where I vent my moans,
I'll beg a tomb for my exiled bones.

div.stage: A flourish. Enter. Menelaus, Diomed, Thersites with Spartan lords: Aeneas, Deiphobus, Antenor, etc.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Now prince of Troy, our business being o'er
This day in Lacedaemon, you shall feast
Paris, we are proud of such a princely guest.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Thus every man is born to his own fate.
Now it reins horns, let each man shield his pate.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: This royalty extended to the welcome
Of Priam's son, is more than Asia's King
Would yield unto the greatest prince of Greece.
What is this Paris whom you honour so?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Why asks my Queen?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: May not this proud ▪ this beauty vaunting Trojan,
In a smooth brow hide black and rugged treason?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: He such an one? rather a giddy brain ▪
A formal traveller. King Diomed
Your censure of this Trojan?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: A capering, carpet knight, a cushion lord,
One that hath stalled his courtly tricks at home,
And now got leave to publish them abroad
did to a stranger prince, it could not though
Leaven my zeal oh you: speak the fairest Queen
That ever spoke, this night shall we agree
To consecrat to pleasure and delights:
Your husband left me charge I should enjoy
All that the court can yield: if all? than you
I would not for the world, but you should do
All that the King your lord commands you too:
Your King and husband, you sin doubly still
When you assent not to obey his will:
Speak beauteous Queen. No? then it may be
She means by silence to accord with me:
I'll try that presently, lend me your hand
'Tis this I want, and by the Kings command
You are to let me have it: more than this,
I want your lips to help me make a kiss.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O love, a joy above all measure,
To touch these lips is more than heavenly pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Beshrew your amorous rhetoric that did prove ▪
My husbands will commanded me to love,
For but for that injunction, Paris know
I would not yield such favours to bestow
On any stranger, but since he commands,
You may take more than either lips or hands.
Do I not blush sweet stranger? if I break
The laws of modesty, think that I speak,
But with my husband's tongue, for I say still
I would not yield, but to obey his will.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This night then without all suspicion,
The ravishing pleasures of your royal bed
You may afford to Paris: bitter Thersites,
King Diomed, and your servants may suppose
By my late counterfeit distemperature
I aim at no such happiness, alas
I am a puny courtier, a weak brain,
A brainsick young man; but divinest Helen,
when we get safe to Troy.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: To Troy?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yes Queen, by all the gods it is decreed,
That I should bear you thither; Priam knows it,
And therefore purposely did rig this fleet,
To waft me hither; he and Hecuba,
My nine and forty brothers, princes all
Of ladies and bright virgins infinite,
Will meet us in the road of Tenedos ▪
Then be resolved for I will cast a plot
To bear you safe from hence!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: This Trojan prince
Will's more than any prince of Greece dares plead,
And yet I have no power to say him nay:
Well Paris I beshrew you with my heart,
That ever you came to Sparta (By my joy
Queen Helen lies, and longs to be at Troy:)
Yet use me as you please, you know you have
My dearest love, and therefore cannot crave
What I'll deny; but if reproach and shame
Pursue us, on you Paris light the blame:
I'll wash my hands of all, nor will I yield
But by compulsion to your least demand:
Yet if in lieu of my King's entertain,
You bid me to a feast aboard your ship,
And when you have me there, unknown to me
Hoist sail, weigh anchor, and bear out to sea ▪
I cannot help it, 'tis not in my power
To let fall sails, or strive with stretching oars
To row me back again: this you may do,
But sooth friend Paris he not yield thereto.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You shall be then compelled, on me let all
The danger waiting on this practice fall.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Castor and Pollux your two princely brothers
Are newly landed, and tomorrow next
Purpose for Lacedaemon ▪

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: On their approach
He lay my plot to escape away with Paris.
I have it: you sir for some special reason
There coming keep concealed, but when tomorrow
You shall perceive me near the water port,
Even when thou seest me ready to take barge.
You apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Gracious Queen I do.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Take that farewell: now my fair princely guest
All that belongs to you's to invite Queen Helen
Aboard your ship tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sparta's mirror,
Will you vouchsafe to a poor wand'ring prince
So much of grace, will your high majesty
Deign the acceptance of an homely banquet
Aboard his weather beaten bark?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: No friend,
The King my husband is from Sparta gone,
And I, till his return, must needs keep home:
Urge me not I entreat, it is in vain
Get me aboard, I'll ne'er turn back again.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Nor shall you lady, Sparta nor all Greece
Shall fetch you thence, but Troy shall stand as high
On terms with Greece, as Greece hath stood with Troy.

sp.speaker: Spa. l.
sp.p: This is the water-port, the Queen's royal guest, hath bound me to attendance, till the prince and she be ready to take water: methinks in this there should be some trick or other, she was once stolen away by Theseus, and this a gallant smooth faced prince. The Kings from home, the Queens but a woman, the Troians ships new trimmed, the wind stands fair, and the sailors all ready aboord, sweetmeats and wine, good words and opportunity, and indeed not what? If both parties be pleased, but pleased or not the music gives warning, are they not now upon their entrance.

div.stage: Enter in state Paris, Hellen, Diomed, thersites, Aeneas, Antenor, Deiphebus, etc. with attendants.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: Health to your majesties, your princely brothers
Castor and Pollux, being within two leagues
Of this great city, come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My brothers stolen upon us unawares.
Let me intreat thee royal Diomed,
And you Thersites, do me so much grace,
As give them friendly meeting.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Queen we shall.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Our entertainment shall be given aboard,
Where I presume, they shall be welcome guests
To princely Paris.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: As to yourself, fair Queen,

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Set forwards then.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: We'll hoist up sail, ne'er to return again.

div.stage: Exeunt the Trojans with a great shout.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Our brother Menelaus gone for Crete?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Our love to see him, makes us lose much time ▪
Yet all our labour is not vainly spent,
Since we shall see our sister.

div.stage: Enter the Spartan lord in haste.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.p: Princes, the Kings betrayed, all Greece dishonoured, the Queen born hence, the Trojans have weighed anchor, and with a prosperous gale they bear from hence:
sp.l: Shouting and hurling up their caps for joy,
They cry farewell to Greece, amain for Troy.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: The Queen born hence, with that smooth traitor Paris.
See princes with what pride they have advanced
The arms of Tray upon their waving pendants.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Rage not, but let's resolve what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Let some ride post to Crete for Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Sp. L.
sp.l: That be my charge.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Who'll after him to sea?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That will my brother Castor and myself,
And perish there, or bring my sister back.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Princes be't so, and fairly may you speed:
Whilst I to Agamemnon, great Achilles,
Ulysses, Nestor, Aiax, Idomean,
And all the Kings and Dukes of populous Greece,
Relate the wrongs done by this ravisher.
Part, and be expeditious ▪

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,
I smelled this sea-rat ere he came ashore, by this he's gnawing
Menelaus' cheese, and made a huge hole in't ▪ ship-diet pleaseth
'Bove all his palace banquets, much good do't them:
They are at it without grace by this both bare:
Cuckold? no subject with that name be sorry,
Since sovereigns may be such in all their glory.

div.head: Actus secundus scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Fair Cressida, by the honour of my birth,
As I am Hector's brother, Priam's son,
And Troilus best beloved of Hecuba,
As I love arms and soldiers, I protest,
Thy beauty lives enshrined here in my breast.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: As I am Calchas daughter, Cressida,
High priest to Pallas, she that patrons Troy:
Now sent unto the Delphian oracle,
To know what shall betide prince Paris voyage.
I hold the love of Troilus dearer far.
Then to be Queen of Asia.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Daughter to Calchas and the pride of Troy,
Plight me your hand and heart.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Fair heaven I do.
Will Troilus in exchange grant me his too?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Yes, and fast sealed, you gods, your anger wreak
On him or her, that first this union break.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: So protests Cressida, wretched may they die,
That 'twixt our souls these holy bands untie.

div.stage: Enter Margaretan one of Priam's youngest sons.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: My brother Troilus, we have news from Greece,
Prince Paris is returned.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: And with a prize?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Asia affords none such.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: What is she worth our aunt Hesione?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Or what might be her name?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Helen of Sparta.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Helen's name
Hath scarce been heard in Troy.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: But now her fame
Will be eternised, for a face more fair
Sun never shone on, nor the earth e'er bare.
Why stay you here? by this Paris and she
Are landed in the port of Tenedos,
There Priam, Hecuba, Hector, all Troy
Meets the midway to attend the Spartan Queen.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: In that fair train, my Cressid shall be seen
Of rarer beauty than the Spartan Queen.

div.stage: A flourish. Enter at one door, Priam, Hecuba, Hector, Troilus, etc. At the other Paris, Hellen, Aeneas, Antenor, etc.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What earth, what all mortality
Can in the height of our inventions find
To add to Helen's welcome, Troy shall yield her.
Should Pallas, patroness of Troy descend,
Priam and Priam's wife, and Priam's sons
could not afford her godhead more applause,
Then amply we bestow on Helena?

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: We count you in the number of our daughters,
Nor can we do Queen Helen greater honour.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I was not forward to have Paris sent,
But being returned thou'rt welcome: I desired not
To have bright Helen brought, but being landed,
Hector proclaims himself her champion
'Gainst all the world, and he shall guard thee safe
Despite all opposition.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hector's word
As oracle, he'll seal it with his sword.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And now my turn comes to bid Helen welcome.
You are no stranger here, this is your Troy,
Priam your father, and this Queen your mother:
These be your valiant brothers, all your friends.
Why should a tear fall from these heavenly eyes
Being thus round ingirt with your allies.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I am I know not where, nor amongst whom,
I know no creature that I see save yond:
I have left my King, my brothers, subjects, friends
For strangers, who should they forsake me now,
I have no husband, father, brother near:

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Have you not all these, is not Paris here?
Hark how the people having Helen seen
Applaud th'arrival of the Spartan Queen:
And millions that your coming have attended,
Amazed swear some goddess is descended.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: No way you can your eyes or body turn,
But where you walk the priests shall incense burn.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: The sacrificed beasts the ground shall beat,
And bright religious fire the altar's heat.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Nor fear the bruit of war or threatening steel,
United Greece we value not.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Alone, by Hector is this town well maned,
He like an army against Greece shall stand.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And who would fear for such a royal wife
to set the universal world at strife:
Bright Helen's name shall live, and ne'er have end,
When all the world about you shall contend.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Be as be may, since we are gone thus far,
Proceed we will in spite of threatened war,
Hazard, and dread? both these we nothing hold,
So long as Paris we may thus enfold.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My father, mother, brothers, sisters all,
Illium and Troy in pomp majestical,
Shall solemnize our nuptials. Let that day
In which we espouse the beauteous Helena,
Be held a holiday, a day of joy
For ever, in the calendars of Troy.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: It shall be so, we have already sent
Our high priest Calchas to the oracle
At Delphos to return us the success,
And a true notice of our future wars,
Whilst we expect his coming, be't our care,
The Spartans second nuptials to prepare.

div.stage: Enter after an alarum, King Agamemnon, Menelaus Achilles, Aiax, Patroclus, Thersites, Calchas, etc.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Thou glory of the Greeks, the great commander
Of the stout Mirmedons: welcome from Delphos,
What speaks the oracle? the sack of Troy?
Or the Greeks ruin? say shall we be victors,
Or Priam triumph in our overthrow.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: The god of Delphos sends you joyful news,
Troy shall be sacked, and we be conquerors:
Upon your helms wear triple spangled plumes:
Let all the loudest instruments of war,
With stern alarms rouse the monster death,
And march we boldly to the walls of Troy,
Troy shall be sacked and we be conquerors.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Thanks for thy news Achilles, by that honour
My father won upon the walls of Troy.
My warlike father Aiax Telamon;
I would not for the world, Priam should send
Incestuous Helen back on terms of peace.
May smooth Ulysses and bold Diomed ▪
Whom you have sent on your late embassy,
Be welcomed as Antenor was to Greece,
Scorned and reviled, since th' oracle hath said,
Troy shall be sacked, and we be conquerors.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: King Agamemnon here's a Trojan priest
Was sent by Priam to the oracle:
The reverent man I welcome, and entreat
The general with these princes, do the like.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Welcome to Agamemnon reverent Calchas.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: To Menelaus welcome.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: To Aiax welcome: father canst thou fight
As well as pray, if we should want for men?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: By prayers I use to fight, and by my counsel
Give aid to arms.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Such as are past arms, father Calchas still,
Say counsels good, but give me strength at will,
When you with all your counsel, in the field
Meet Hector with his strength, tell me who'll yield?

sp.speaker: Aga,
sp.l: The strong built walls of stately Tenedos
We have levelled with the earth. It now remains
We march along unto the walls of Troy,
And thunder vengeance in King Priam's ears,
Had we once answer of our embassy.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: I ever held such embassies as base,
The restitution of our ravished Queen
On terms of parley bars our stern revenge,
And ends our war ere fully it begin.
King Agamemnon no, Aiax say no,
Whose sword as thirsty as the parched earth,
Shall never ride in peace upon his thigh,
Whilst in the town of Troy there breathes a soul
That gave consent unto the Spartans rape:
March, march, and let the thunder of our drums
strike terror to the city Pergamus.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: The son of Telamon speaks honourably,
We have brought a thousand ships to Tenedos,
And every ship full fraught with men at arms:
And all these armed men with fiery spirits
Sworn to revenge King Menelaus wrongs,
And burn sky-kissing Lllium to the ground.
Therefore strike up wars instruments on high,
And march unto the town courageously.

div.stage: In their march they are met by Ulysses and King Diomed, at which they make a stand.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Princes, what answer touching Helena?

sp.speaker: Di●.
sp.l: What answer but dishonourable term?
Contempt and scorn perched on their leaders brows,
By Jove I thought they would have slain us both.
If ever Helen be redeemed from thence
But by the sack of Troy, say Diomed
Is no true soldier.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Even in the King
There did appear such high majestic scorn
Of threatened ruin, that I think himself
Will put on arms and meet us in the field:
We linger time great Agamemnon, march,
That we may buckle with the pride of Troy.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Priam so insolent, his sons so brave
To entertain so great ambassadors
With such ungentle usage.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: They have a knight called Hector, on whose valour
They build their proud defiance, if I meet him,
Now by the azured arms of that bright goddess
From whom I am descended, with my sword
I'll lop that limb off, and enforce their pride
Fall at Achilles' feet, Hector and I
Must nor both shine at once in wars bright sky.

sp.speaker: Ajax
sp.l: When they both meet, the greater dim the less,
Great general, march, Aiax endures not words
so well as blows, in a field glazed with swords.

div.stage: Enter to them in arms, Priam, Hector, Troilus, Paris, Aeneas, Antenor, Deiphobus, etc.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Calchas a traitor?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And amongst the Greeks?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Base runagate wretch, when we their tents surprise,
As Hector lives the traitorous prophet dies.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Let not remembrance of so base a wretch
Make us forget our safety, th' Argive Kings ▪
Are landed, and this day raced Tenedos:
And bid us battle on Scamander plains.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Whom we will give a brave and proud affront;
Shall we not brother Hector?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Troilus yes,
And beat a fire out of their burgonets
Shall like an earthy comet blaze towards heaven
There grow a fixed star in the firmament
To emblaze our lasting glory: hark their drums,
Let our drums give them parlance.

div.stage: A parley. Both armies have an interview.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Is there amongst your troops a felon prince
Called by the name of Paris?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is there amongst your troops a knight so bold
Dares meet that Paris single in the field,
And call him felon?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Or insulting Greek,
Is there one Telamon, dares set his foot
To Paris (Here he stands) and hand to hand
Maintain the wrongs done to Hesione,
As Paris shall the rape of Helena.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Know here is one called Aiax Telamon,
Behold him well, son to that Telamon:
Thou fain wouldst see, and he dares set his foot
To Paris or thyself.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thou durst not.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Dare not?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Or if thou durst, by this my warlike hand
I'll make thine head fall where thy foot should stand:
And yet I love thee coz, know thou hast parleyed
With Trojan Hector.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Were't thou ten Hectors, yet withal thy might
Thou canst not make my head fall to my feet,
By Jove thou canst not coz.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I much have heard
Of such a knight called by the name of Hector,
If thou beest he whose sword hath conquered kingdoms,
Pannonia, illyria, and Samothrace,
And to thy father's empire added them:
Achilles as a friend wills thee to sheathe
Thy warlike sword, retire from Troy's defence
And spare thy precious life, I would not have
A knight so famed meet an untimely grave.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I meet thee in that honourable love,
And for thine own sake wish thee safe aboard.
For if thou stayest thou son of Peleus,
I'd have thee know thy fame is not thine own,
But all engrossed for me; not all thy guard
Of warlike Myrmidons can wall i●●a●e
From mighty Hector.

sp.speaker: Di●.
sp.l: Shame you not great lords
To talk so long over your menacing swords?

sp.speaker: All Greeks.
sp.l: Alarm then for Greece and Helena.

sp.speaker: All Trojans.
sp.l: As much for us, for Troy and Hecuba.

div.stage: A great alarm and excursions, after which, enter Hector and Paris.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O brother Paris, thou hast this day lodged
Thy love in Hector's soul, it did me good
To see two Greekish knights fall in their blood
Under thy manly arm

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My blows were touches
Unto these ponderous strokes great Hector gave.
O that this general quarrel might be ended
In equal opposition, you and I
Against the two most valiant.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I will try
The virtue of a challenge, in the face
Of all the Greeks I will oppose myself
To single combat, he that takes my gage
Shall feel the force of mighty Hector's rage.

div.stage: A turn. Both the armies make ready to join battle, but Hector steps betwixt them holding up his lance.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Hear me you warlike Greeks, you see these fields
Are all died purple with the reeking gore
Of men on both sides slain, you see my sword
Glazed in the sanguine moisture of your friends.
I call the son of Saturn for a witness
To Hector's words I have not met one Grecian
Was able to withstand me, my strong spirit
Would fain be equalled: is there in your troops
A knight, whose breast includes so much of valour
To meet with Hector in a single war?
By Jove I think there is not: if there be?
To him I make this proffer; if the gods
Shall grant to him the honour of the day,
And I be slain; his be mine honoured are mes,
To hang for an eternal monument
Of his great valour, but my mangled body
Send back to Troy, to a red funeral pile.
But if he fall? the armour which he wears
I'll lodge as trophies on Apollo's shrine,
And yield his body to have funeral rights.
And a fair monument so near the sea,
That merchants flying in their sail-winged ships
Near to the shore in after times may say ▪
there lies the man Hector of Troy did slay,
And there's my gauntlet to make good my challenge.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Will none take up his gage? shall this proud challenge
Be entertained by none? I know you all
Shame to deny, yet fear to undertake it:
The cause is mine, and mine shall be the honour
To combat Hector.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Menelaus pause,
Is not Achilles here, stern Aiax here,
And kingly Diomed ▪ how will they scorn,
That stand upon the honour of their strength,
Should you prevent them of this glorious combat.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: By Jove I think they dare as well take up
A poisonous serpent as great Hector's gage.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Yes Trojan, seest thou not Aeacides
Dart emulous looks on kingly Diomed,
Lest he should stoop to take his gauntlet up.
And see how Diomed eyes warlike Aiax,
Aiax, Ulysses: every one inflamed
To answer Hector.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Is there any here
Dares stoop whilst great Achilles is in place?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: I dare.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: And so dare I.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: You are all too weak
To encounter with the mighty Hector's arm,
This combat solely doth belong to me.

sp.speaker: Aiax
sp.l: Then wherefore dost not thou take up the gauntlet?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: To see if thou or any bolder Greek
Dare be so insolent to touch the same,
And bar me of the honour of the combat.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: By all the gods I dare.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: And all the devils
I'll lop his hands off that dares touch the gage.

sp.speaker: Ulyss.
sp.l: Pray leave this emulous fury: Agamemnon,
To end this difference, and provide a champion
To answers Hector's honourable challenge
of nine the most reputed valiant:
Let several lots be cast into an helm,
Amongst them all one prize, he to whom fortune
Shall give the honour: let him straight be armed
To encounter mighty Hector on this plain.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: It shall be so you valiant sons of Priam:
Conduct your warlike champion to his tent,
To breathe a while, and put his armour on:
No sooner shall the prize be drawn by any,
And our bold champion armed, but a brave herald
Shall give you warning by the trumpets sound,
Till when we will retire unto our tents.
As you unto the town.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Faint hearted Greeks,
Draw lots to answer such a noble challenge,
Had great Achilles cast his gauntlet down
Amongst King Priam's sons, the weakest of fifty
Would in the heat of flames, or mouth of hell,
Answer the challenge of so brave a King.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Greeks to your tents, to put armour on;
Make haste, I long to know my champion.

div.stage: Flourish. Enter above upon the walls, Priam, Hecuba, Helena, Polixena, Aftianax, Margareton. with attendants.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Here from the walls of Troy, my reverent Queen,
And beauteous Helen, we will stay to see
The warlike combat 'twixt our valiant son,
And the Greeks champion. Young Astyanax,
Pray that thy father may have victory.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.l: Why should you doubt his fortune? whose strong arm
Unhorsed a thousand knights all in one day;
And think you any one amongst the Greeks
Is able to encounter with his strength?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: But howsoever child, unto the pleasure ▪
Of the high gods, we must refer the combat.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My royal father, Hector in his arms
Sends for your blessing, with the Queen my mother,
And craves your prayers to the all powerful gods,
To grant him victory.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Blessed may he be with honour, all my orisons
Shall invocate the gods for his success.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I almost had forgotten fair Helena;
Dart me one kiss from these high battlements
To cheer him with: thanks Queen these lips are charms
Which who so fights for, is secure from harms.

div.stage: Heralds on both sides ▪ the two champions Hector and Aiax appear betwixt the two armies.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: None press too near the champions.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Heralds on both sides, keep the soldiers back.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Now Greeks let me behold my champion.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: 'Tis I, thy cousin Aiax Telamon.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: And coz, by Jove thou hast a brave aspect,
It cheers my blood to look on such a foe:
I would there ran none of our Trojan blood
In all thy veins, or that it were divided
From that which thou receivest from Telamon:
Were I assured our blood possessed one side,
And that the other; by Olympic Jove,
I'd thrill my javelin at the Grecian moisture,
And spare the Trojan blood: Aiax I love it
Too dear to shed it, I could rather wish
Achilles the half god of your huge army,
Had been my opposite.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: He keeps his tent
In mournful passion that he missed the combat:
But Hector, I shall give thee cause to say,
There's in the Greekish host a knight a prince,
As lion hearted, and as giant strong
As Thetis son: behold my warlike target
Of ponderous brass, quilted with seven ox hides,
Impenetrable, and so full of weight,
that scarce a Grecian (Sane myself) can lift it:
Yet can I use it like a summer's fan,
Made of the stately train of Juno's bird:
My sword will bite the hardest adamant.
I'll with my javelin cleave a rock of marble:
Therefore though great Achilles be not here,
Think not brave cousin Hector but to find,
Achilles equal both in strength and mind.

div.stage: Alarum, in this combat both having lost their swords and shields. Hector takes up a great piece of a rock, and casts at Aiax; who tears a young tree up by the roots, and assails Hector, at which they are parted by both arms.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Hold, you have both shed blood too dear to lose,
In single opposition.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is your champion,
My cousin Aiax willing to leave combat;
Will he first give the word.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Sir Paris no,
'Twas Hector challenge, and 'tis Hector's office,
If we surcease on equal terms of valour,
To give the word.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Then here's thy cousin's hand,
By Jove thou hast a lusty ponderous arm:
Thus till we meet again, let's part both friends;
For proof whereof Aiax we'll interchange
Somewhat betwixt us, for alliance' sake:
Here take this sword and target, trust the blade,
It never deceived his master.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Take of me
This purple studded belt, I won it cousin
From the most valiant prince of Samothrace:
And wear it for my sake.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Priam unto the Greekish general
This proffer makes. Because these bloodstained fields
are overspread with slaughter, to take truce
Till all the dead on both sides be interred:
Which if you grant, he here invites the general,
His nephew Aiax, and the great Achilles,
With twenty of your chief selected princes,
To banquet with him in his royal palace:
Those revels ended, then to arms again.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: A truce for burying of the slaughtered bodies
We yield unto: but for our safe return
From Troy and you, what pledges have you found?

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: You shall not need more than the faith of Hector
For Priam's pledge, King Agamemnon take
My faith and honour, which if Priam break,
I'll break the heart of Troy.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: We'll take your honoured word, this night we'll part,
Tomorrow morning when fit hour shall call,
We'll meet King Priam near his city's wall.

div.head: Actus tertius scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Brave time, rare change, from fighting now to feasting:
So many heavy blades to fly in pieces
For such a piece of light flesh? what's the reason?
A lass of my complexion, and this feature
Might have been rapt, and stolen again by Paris,
And none of all this stir for't: but I perceive
Now all the world's turned wenchers, and in time
All wenches will turn witches: but these trumpets
Proclaim their interview.

div.stage: A flourish. Enter all the Greeks on one side, all the Trojans on the other: every Trojan prince entertains a Greek, and so march two and two, discoursing, as being conducted by them into the city.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: See here's the picture of a politic state,
They all embrace and hug, yet deadly hate:
They say their are brave lasses in this Troy.
What if Thersites sprucely smuged himself,
And strived to hide his hunchback: no not I.
'Tis held a rule, whom nature marks in show
And most deforms, they are best armed below.
I'll not conceal my virtues: yet should I venture
To dam myself for painting, fan my face
With a dyde ostrich plume, plaster my wrinkles
With some old lady's trowel, I might pass
Perhaps for some maid-marian: and some wench
Wanting good eyesight, might perhaps mistake me
For a spruce courtier: courtier? tush, I from
My first discretion have abhorred that name,
Still suiting my conditions with my shape,
And do, and will, and can, when all else fail:
Though neither sooth nor speak well: bravely rail,
And that's Thersites humour.

div.stage: Loud music. A long table, and abanquet in state, they are seated, a Trojan and Greek, Hecuba, Polixena, Cresida, and other ladies wait, Calchas is present whispering with his daughter Cresida.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: After so much hostility in steel,
All welcome to this peaceful entertain.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Priam we know thee to be honourable,
Although our foe treason is to be feared
In peasants not in princes.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Ay so, now sit a Trojan and a Greek.
Cousin Aiax near me, you are next in blood,
And near me you shall sit: the strain of honour
That makes you so renowned, sprung from Hesione.
'tis part of Hector's blood, your grosser spirits
Less noble are your father Telamon's.
Welcome to Troy, and Hector, welcome all:

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: In Troy thy kinsman, but in field thy foe:
Thy welcome cousin here I pay with thanks,
The truce expired, with buffets blows and knocks.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: For that we love the coz.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Methinks this Trojan Hector
Out shines Achilles and his polished honours
Eclipseth our bright glory, till he set
We cannot rise.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: King Menelaus, we were once your guest,
You now are ours, as welcome unto Troy,
As we to Sparta.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: But that these our tongues
Should be as well truce bound as our sharp weapons,
We could be bitter Paris: but have done.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Menelaus is discreet, such heinous wrongs
Should be discoursed by arms and not by tongues.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why doth Achilles eye wander that way?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Is that a Trojan lady?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: She is.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Of us.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Her name?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Polyxena.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Polixena? she hath melted us within,
And hath dissolved a spirit of adamant.
She hath done more than Hector and all Troy,
She hath subdued Achilles.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: In one word this Troy shall be sacked and spoiled,
For so the gods have told me, Greece shall conquer,
And they be ruined, leave then imminent peril,
And fly to safety.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: From Troilus?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: From destruction, take Diomed and live,
Or Troilus and thy death.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Then Troilus and my ruin.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Is Cressid mad?
sp.p: Wilt thou forsake thy father, who for thee and for thy safety hath forsook his country?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Must then this city perish?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Troy must fall.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Alas for Troy and Troilus.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Love King Diomed
A prince and valiant, which made emphasis
To his imperial style, line Diomedes' Queen,
Be brief, say quickly wilt thou? is it done?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Diomed and you I'll follow, Troilus shun.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Be't Aiax, or Achilles, that Greek lies
Who speaks it, I'll maintain it on his person.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Ha Aiax!

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Achilles!

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: We speak it, and dares Troilus say we lie?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: And wear it Diomed.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Dar'st thou make't good?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: On Diomed, or the boldest Greek
That ever menaced Troy excepting none.

sp.speaker: All Greeks.
sp.l: None?

sp.speaker: All Trojans.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Excepting none.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Kings of Greece.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Princes of Troy.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Achilles baffled?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: And great Aiax brained?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: If great Achilles, Aiax, or the devil brave Troilus, he shall brave and buffer thee.

sp.speaker: P●i.
sp.l: Sons.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Fellow Kings.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: As we are Priam and your father.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: As we are Agamemnon general
Turn not this banquet to a centaur's feast,
If their be strife debate it in fair terms,
show your selves governed princes.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: We are appeased

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: We satisfied, if Hector be so.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: How grew this strife?

sp.speaker: Hect
sp.l: I know not, only this I know.
Troilus will maintain nothing against his honour,
And so far, be it through the heart of Greece,
Hector will back him.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: So will Paris too.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Mildly discourse your wrongs, fair prince's do.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: King Diomed maintains his valour thus,
He saith it was his lance dismounted Troilus,
And not the stumbling on the breathless course
Of one new slain that felled me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Par
sp.l: It was my fortune to make good that field,
And he fell just before me, Diomed then
Was not within six spears length of the place.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: How Trojan ravisher?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Call me not cuckold maker,
I care not what you term me.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I cannot brook this wrong.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Say'st thou me so mad Greek?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Paris.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Govern you kingdoms lords, and cannot sway
Your own affection?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Paris, forbear.
Mildly discourse, and gently we shall hear.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I say King Diomed unhorsed not Troilus.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How came I by his horse then?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: As the unbacked courser having lost his rider,
Galloped about the field you met with him,
And catched him by the rain.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Here was a goodly act
To boast on, and send word to Cressida.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Was no prince near when I encountered Troilus?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I was, and saw the spear of Diomed
Tumble down Troilus but peruse his armour ▪
The dint's still in the vainbrace.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Be't so or not so, at this time forbear
To urge extremes. Kings let this health go round,
Pledge me King Priam in a cupful crowned.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Now after banquet, 〈◊〉 music strike
A pyrrhic strain, we are not all for war,
Soldiers their stormy spirits can appease,
And sometimes play the courtiers when they please.

div.stage: A lofty dance of sixteen princes, half Trojans half Grecians.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I have observed Achilles, and his eye
Dwells on the face of fair Polixena.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Why is not Helen here at this high feast?
I have sweat many a drop of blood for her,
Yet never saw her face.

sp.speaker: Achi
sp.l: I could love Hector, what's our cause of quarrel?
For Helen's rape? that rape hath cost already
Thousands of souls, why might not this contention
Betwixt Paris and the Spartan King be ended,
And we leave Troy with honour.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Achilles how?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Fetch Helen hither, set her in the midst
Of this brave ring of princes, Paris here,
And Menelaus here: she betwixt both:
They court her o'er again, whom she elects
Before these Kings, let him enjoy her still,
For who would keep a woman 'gainst her will?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The names of wife and husband, th'interchange
Of our two bloods in young Hermione,
To whom we are joint parents, Helen's honour
All plead on my part, I am pleased to stand
To great Achilles' motion.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: So are we.
All that I have for comfort is but this,
that in the day I show the properer man,
Ith' night I please her better than he can.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Are all the Grecian Kings agreed to this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are, we are.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Place the two rivals then, each bide his fate ▪
And usher in bright Helen in all state.

div.stage: The Kings promiscuously take their places, Paris and Menelaus are seated opposite, Hellen is brought in betwixt them by Hecuba and the ladies.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: O that I were (But Helen) any thing ▪
Or might have any object in my eye
Save Menelaus: when on him I gaze,
My error chides me, I my shame emblaze.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: O Helen, in thy cheek thy guilt appears,
More I would speak, but words are drowned in tears,

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: A gallant Queen, for such a royal friend
What mortal man would not with Jove contend?

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Helen the time was I might call thee wife,
But that style's changed; I ▪ thou thyself art changed
From what thou wast: and (Most inconstant dame)
Hast nothing left thee, save thy face and name.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: And I both these have: hast thou not confessed
Fair Helen, thy exchange was for the best.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What can our Sparta value?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Troy.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: You err.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Who breathes that Sparta would 'fore Troy prefer.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Thou hast left thy father Tyndarus.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: To gain
King Priam, lord of all this princely train.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Thy mother Lada thou hast left who mourns ▪
And with her piteous tears laments thy loss:
Cannot this move thee?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: O I have left my mother.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No Helen, but exchanged her for another:
Poor Leda, for rich Hecuba, a bare Queen
for the great Asian empress.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: From Castor and from Pollux thou hast ranged
Thy natural brothers.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: True, true.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: No, but changed,
For Hector, Troilus, and the royal store
Of eight and forty valiant brothers more.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: If nothing else can move thee Helena,
Think of our daughter young Hermione.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My dear Hermione.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Canst thou call her dear ▪
And leave that issue which thy womb did bear?
She's ours betwixt us, canst thou?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Can she? knowing,
A sweeter babe within her sweet womb growing
Begotten last night by Paris.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Look this way Helen, see my arms spread wide,
I am thine husband, thou my Spartan bride.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That way?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My Helen, this way turn thy sight,
These are the arms in which thou layest last night.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: O how this Trojan tempts me!

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: This way wife,
Thou shalt save many a Greeks and Trojans life ▪

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I know it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This way turn thine head,
This is the path that leads unto our bed.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: And 'tis a sweet smooth path.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Take this way Helen, this is plain and even.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That is the way to hell, but this to heaven:
Bright comet shine this way.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Clear star shoot this ▪
Here honour dwells.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Here many a thousand kiss.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: That way I should, because I know 'tis 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Welcome.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: But I'll this way for Paris kisses sweeter.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And may I die an eunuch if ere morn
I quit thee not.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I cannot brook this scorn,
Grecians to arms.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Then Greece from Troy divide,
This difference arms, not language most decide.

sp.speaker: All Greeks.
sp.l: Come to our tents.

sp.speaker: All Trojans.
sp.l: And we to man the town.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: These tents shall swim in blood.

sp.speaker: Greeks.
sp.l: Blood Troy shall drown.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Yet shall no stroke fall from Achilles' arm,
Fair Polixena, so powerful is thy charm.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: King Diomed!

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: My rival in the love of Cresida.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: False Cressida, injurious Diomed.
Now shall I prove in hostile interchange
Of warlike blows that thou art all unworthy
The love of Cressid.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why cam'st thou not on horseback ▪
That Diomed once again dismounting thee
Might greet his lady with another course
Won from the hand of Troilus.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Diomed,
By the true love I bear that trothless dame
I'll win thee, and send thy horse and armour
Unto the tent of Cressid guard thy head,
This day by me thou shalt be captive led.

div.stage: Alarm. They fight and are parted by the army ▪ Diomed loseth his helmet.

sp.speaker: Troi
sp.l: Another horse for Diomed to fly,
He had never greater need than now to run.
Though he be fled yet Troilus this is thine.
My steed he got by sleight, I this by force.
I'll send her this to whom he sent my horse.

div.stage: Enter Aeneas and Achilles reading a letter.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Is this the answer of the note I sent
To royal Priam and Queen Hecuba,
Touching their daughter bright Polixena?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Behold Queen Hecuba's hand, King Priam's seal,
With the consent of fair Polixena,
Conditioned thus, Achilles shall forbear
To damage Troy.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Return this answer back,
Tell Priam that Achilles arm's benumbed,
And cannot lift a weapon against Troy.
Say to Queen Hecuba we are her son,
And not Achilles, nor one Myrmidon
Shall give her least affront, as for the lady
Bid her presume, we henceforth are her knight,
And but for her, Achilles scorns to fight.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Then thus saith Priam, but restrain thy powers,
And as he is a King, his daughter's yours.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Achilles, where's Achilles, what unarmed,
When all the champagne where our battles joins,
Is made a standing pool of Greekish blood ▪
Where horses plunged up to the saddle skirts ▪
And men above the waste wade for their lines,
And canst thou keep thy tent?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: My lute Patroclus.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Let Greeks, kill Greeks, let's bend unnatural arms
Against our own breasts, ere the conquering Trojans
Have all the honour of this glorious day.
Can our great champion touch a womanish lute,
And hear the groans of twenty thousand souls
Gasping their last breath?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: I can.

div.l: Rescue, some rescue, the red field is strewed
With Hector's honours and young Troilus spoils.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Yet all this moves not me.

sp.speaker: Ulyss.
sp.p: How long hath great Achilles been surnamed coward in Troy, that Hector, Troilus, Paris, have all that name so currant in their mouths?
sp.l: I ever held him valiant, yet will Achilles fight?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Ulysses, no,
Beneath this globe Achilles hath no foe.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Then here unarmed be slain, think'st thou they'll spare
Thee more than us?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Or if thou wilt not arm thee,
Let thy Patroclus lead thy Myrmidons,
And wear thy armour.

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Thy armour is sufficient ▪
Without thy presence being feared in Troy.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: To save our oath and keep our tents from sack,
Patroclus don our arms, lead forth our guard,
And wearing them by no prince be outdared.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: Achilles honours me, what heart can fear,
And great Achilles' sword proof armour wear?

div.stage: Exeunt all the princes, enter Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Where's this great sword and buckler man of Greece?
We shall have him one of sneak's noise,
And come peaking into the tents of the Greeks,
With will you have any music gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Base groom, I'll tear thy flesh like falling snow ▪

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: If I had Hector's face thou durst not do't.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Dared not?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Dared not, he's in the field, thou in thy tent,
Hector playing upon the Greekish burgonets,
Achilles fingering his effeminate lute.
sp.p: And now because thou durst not meet him in the field, thou hast counterfeited an humour of love. Achilles?
Thou the champion of Greece, a mere bugbear ▪ a scarecrow, a hobby-horse.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Ulysses taught thee this, deformed slave.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Coward thou durst not do this to Hector.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: On thee I'll practise, till I meet with him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Aiax is valiant, and in the throng of the Trojans,
Achilles is turned fiddler in the tents of
The Grecians.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Diomed wounded, bringing in Patroclus dying.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Look here Achilles.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Patroclus?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: This wound great Hector gave:
Revenge my death, before I meets my grave.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Yet will Achilles fight? see Aiax wounded,
Two hundred of thy warlike Mirmedons
Thou hast lost this day.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Let's beat him to the field.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Had I lost a Patroclus, a dear friend
As thou hast dove, I would have donned these arms
In which he died, sprung through the Trojan host,
And maugre opposition, let the blow
Or by the same hand died: come join with me,
And we without this picture, statue of Greece,
This shadow of Achilles, will once more
Invade the Trojan host.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Aiax?

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Achilles?

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: We owe thee for this scorn.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: I scorn that debt:
Thou hast not fought with Hector.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: My honour and my oath both combat in me:
But love sways most.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Our ships are fired, five hundred gallant vessels ▪
Burned in the sea, half of our fleet destroyed,
Without some present rescue.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Doth no man ask where is this double fire,
That two ways flies towards heaven?
Upon the right our royal navy burns,
Upon the left, Achilles' tents on fire.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: Our tent?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: By Jove thy tent, and all thy Mirmedons,
Have not the power to quench it: yet great Hector
Hath shed more blood this day, then would have served
To quench, both fleet and tent.

sp.speaker: Achi.
sp.l: My sword and armour:
Polixena, thy love we will lay by,
Till by this hand, that Trojan Hector die.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: I knew he must be fired out.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Hector, Paris, Troilus, Aeneas, with burning staves and fireballs.

sp.speaker: All the Trojans.
sp.l: Strike, stab, wound, kill, toss firebrands, and make way.
Hector of Troy, and a victorious day.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Well fought brave brothers.

sp.speaker: Pa
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: 'Tis Aiax, down with him.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: No man presume to dart a feather at him
Whilst we have odds: cousin if thou seekest combat?
See we stand single, not one Trojan here,
Shall lay a violent hand upon thy life,
Save we ourself.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Cousin thou'rt honourable,
I now must both entreat and conjure thee ▪
For my old uncle Priam's sake, his sister
Hesione my mother, and thine aunt:
This day leave thine advantage, spare our fleet,
And let us quench our tents, only this day
stay thy victorious hand, 'tis Aiax pleads ▪
Who but of Jove hath never begged before,
And save of Jove, will not entreat again ▪

sp.speaker: All Trojans.
sp.l: Burn, still more fire.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I'll quench it with his blood
That adds one spark unto this kindled flame ▪
My cousin shall not for Hesione's sake
Be ought denied of Hector, she's our aunt:
Thou, than this day hast saved the Grecian fleet:
Let's sound retreat, whose charge made all Greece quake,
We spare whole thousands for one Aiax sake.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: Worthiest alive thou hast, Greece was this day
At her last cast, had they pursued advantage:
But I divine, hereafter from this hour,
We never more shall shrink beneath their power.

div.head: Actus quartus scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter Hector, Troilus, Paris, Aeneas, Hector's armour bearer, with others.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: My armour, and my trusty Galatee,
The proudest steed that ever rider backed,
Or with his hooves beat thunder from the earth,
The sun begins to mount the Eastern hill,
And we not yet in field: lords yesterday
We slipped a brave advantage, else these ships
That float now in the Samothracian road,
And with their waving pendants menace Troy,
Had with their flames reflecting from the sea,
Gilt those high towers, which now they proudly brave.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: On then; Achilles is unconquered yet,
great Agamemnon and the Spartan King,
Aiax the big-boned Duke of Salamine,
With him that with his lance made Kenus bleed,
The bold, (But ever rash) King Diomed.
To lead these captive through Scamander plains ▪
That were a task worth Hector.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.l: Why not us?
Yet most becoming him, come then Aeneas,
Let each pick one of these brave champions out
And single him a captive.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: ''twere an enterprise
That would deserve a lasting chronicle:
